Here’s the problem… you spent all your money on 
a sick, RGB infused, gaming PC. And now your

wallet is as empty as your hard drive. How are 
you supposed to afford any games!!??!?!
HUMBLE BUNDLE
And the HUMBLE BUNDLE SUMMER SALE OF GREAT DEALS!

Save up to 90% on thousands of games in Humble’s

Games like Deep Rock Galactic,

The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt complete edition at 70% off!!

And Humble Bundle Choice users can get up to 20%

All of these great deals and every Bundle or game

Use the link in the description to head to 
HumbleBundle.com to gaze upon the plethora of

percentages before the Summer Sale ends on 
September 5th.&quot;
[Intro Music]

So I hear the new Baldurs Gate is making bank 
like a knicker elastic shop next door to a French

burlesque club - I don&#39;t know, it made sense in 
my head.

And a lot of people are going, &quot;Ooh,
finally gamers send a clear message that they want

good single-player games with strong
design and narrative, not just fancy graphics and
live service to Atari.&quot;

To which I reply, &quot;You mean, besides
the previous 12 times they sent that message?&quot;

I mean, Christ, at this point it feels
like saying &quot;prisoners in basements send clear

message that they&#39;d rather not
be sodomized with a 6&quot; wooden dowel.

But is Baldur&#39;s Gate 3 actually good or
just riding the wave of metaphorical demand for
dowel removal and soothing bum cream?

I&#39;d never been one with this sort of
top-down clicky RPG before, but a couple of significant
factors drew me to this one.

Editor Nick strongly suggested I give it
a look, saying it&#39;s doing some full-on immersive
sim stuff that sets it apart.

Ooh, you mean you can
break doors and stack crates?

And the second factor was that since the
last D&amp;D-based video game I have become a D&amp;D player
IRL.

Tune into Adventure is Nigh every
other Saturday only on The Escapist plug plug.

So when I started the game and the
screen became deluged with icons like it was being

subjected to the wrath of Windows 95, I
understood what some of them meant, and I could go in

already knowing things that both
Baldur&#39;s Gate 3 and D&amp;D generally are really sodding
bad at explaining.
Like how the cocking sneak attack works.

On that note, I also thought it best to
try out the game&#39;s flexibility by roleplaying

as my existing D&amp;D character Mortimer,
a Weasily Con artist who min-maxes deception

in order to weasel his way out of
problems because he&#39;s as much use in a fight as an
actual weasel.

So the game starts and we&#39;re on an alien
spaceship that crashlands for various complicated

reasons and we have to fight our way
out of the wreckage, fending off purple squiddly

dudes in robes, and I&#39;m all like
&quot;Sorry, did we come in the wrong door?

I&#39;m here for Baldur&#39;s Gate, why are
we in the last mission of an XCOM game?&quot;

But then we get away from the crash
site and we&#39;re in more traditional D&amp;D land.

Forests in battled villages, dungeons,
can&#39;t move ten steps without hitting a trap or a
gelatinous cube.

We also swiftly load up the party bus
with a bunch of fellow escapees and adventurers
all with diverse classes and complex backstories

but more importantly
representing a nice convenient
meat shield for Mortimer to hide behind.

Turns out everyone&#39;s got squirmy worms
in their brains that will turn them into the

purple squiddly dudes within days
if we don&#39;t find a way to hack them out.

And so we&#39;re set loose to adventure our way
through that problem by dealing with 500 different
ones.

And as the ground level gameplay kicked
in, it soon became clear that the game wasn&#39;t

going to let me hide at the back of the
party, plucking my fantasy banjo and slinging the

odd vicious mockery like the most
infuriating little tit at the hoedown contest.

You&#39;ve got to micromanage all your party
members&#39; actions and levelling choices, if you don&#39;t

go through them all individually telling
them to go into stealth mode they&#39;ll blunder in

after your sneaky ass like three
embarrassing parents coming to pick you up from the school
disco.

The world is extremely flexible with
letting you make crazy jumps to bypass obstacles,

but the pathfinding frequently has
trouble keeping up, something I was able to exploit

to my favour during one combat sequence
where I kept moving to the other side of a huge

pit and causing two minotaurs to keep
getting confused and changing direction like we were

chasing a nervous bride
around a honeymoon sweet coffee table.

One thing I swiftly learned was that
whenever negotiation broke down and a conversation

turned into combat I would usually get a
lot of little goblin sized boot prints all over

my buttocks because deceiving and
weaseling out at combat only worked often enough to

make me completely bloody
unprepared for the unavoidable fights.

The winning strategy in such cases was
to reload a save and try to cheat as much as

possible which wasn&#39;t great for
immersion, there was no in-universaries in why Mortimer

would drag an explosive barrel into
the middle of a group of not-yet-hostile NPCs.

Don&#39;t mind me, I just
thought this would look nice here.

My goodness, your leader&#39;s
making a jolly interesting speech.

Why don&#39;t you keep paying attention to
that while I go over there and check on that thing
that&#39;s just inside Firebolt range.

I also got a lot of mileage
out of shoving people off cliffs.

Ballerskate 3 will never use an
impassable wall when a bottomless chasm will do.

Even when there wasn&#39;t one sometimes I&#39;d
just climb to the highest point, make the enemy

chase me up there, then shove them
straight back off like an asshole kid on a climbing
frame.

Three rounds of that I was
starting to feel sorry for the stupid bastard.

Although the enemy AI seems pretty
clued in on the patented labour-saving cliff shove

technique as well, so I was still
having to retry combat encounters a lot.

I saw a tweet this week saying &quot;Hey,
don&#39;t reload after every mistake, roll with it,

find a solution, that&#39;s
how you have fun with Baldur&#39;s Gate.

Fine sentiment, except all my mistakes
seem to end with my party getting pounded into
mulch.

Not sure how I&#39;m supposed to roll with
that unless it happens at the top of a staircase
or angled surface.&quot;

Maybe this was a consequence of my
choices in life, but I felt I kept getting trapped

in situations where
grueling combat was unavoidable.

&quot;I guess one mission to rescue
the Druid leader from a goblin camp.&quot;

I bullshitted my way in and found the
dude easily enough, but then he was like &quot;Ooh

I can&#39;t escape with you or consider this
quest complete until you kill all three goblin leaders.&quot;

Now said dude had the ability to turn
into a giant bear, which would tip scales in our

favour a tad, but wouldn&#39;t come with
us at first, &quot;Oh I could come rip shit up, but

then you&#39;d lose the opportunity
to kill your target stealthily,&quot; he said.

&quot;Oh, sure, I was totally gonna stealth
kill three high level goblin leaders in full view

of nine of their guards
and within earshot of twenty more.
I&#39;ll get right on that.
Get in the fucking party bus, Teddy Ruxpin.&quot;

So I don&#39;t entirely buy this popular
possession that Baldurs Gate 3 is a super flexible game

where every problem has multiple
solutions, but I&#39;m sure I barely scratched the surface
of it in my usual limited one week of playtime.

I mean, it&#39;s no graphics powerhouse and
the file size descended upon my hard drive like
a fat bloke into a crowded bus seat.

I wonder how much of its sudden popularity
is due to outside factors, the growing distaste

for the usual tedious gameplay loops
and online flattery, the increasing popularity

of D&amp;D thanks to actual play series&#39;s
Adventure Is Nigh Season 3 is airing now don&#39;t miss out
cross promote cross promote.
But you know what, viewer?

For all the times I got backed into a
prolonged frustrating combat, having been left to randomly

explore a new area only to discover
afterwards that it did soddle to get me any closer to
my goal, something made me keep pressing on.

Something always made me want to survive
this and see what was around the next corner, and

I think that comes down to being a just
plain, solidly built game in terms of narrative and
discovery.

I wanted to keep learning more about my
situation and my party members, specifically what they
kept inside their underpants.
It was vaginas.
